Award.AwardTitle: Neuroendocrine Bases and Environmental Regulation of Reproduction in a Flexibly Breeding Songbird
Award.AbstractNarration:
PROJECT TITLE: Neuroendocrine Bases and Environmental Regulation of Reproduction in a Flexibly Breeding Songbird

PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR: Pierre Deviche, Arizona State University

PROJECT NUMBER: IOS 1026620

This project will combine field studies on free-ranging organisms with experiments in a controlled laboratory setting to investigate the neuroendocrine bases of vertebrate reproductive flexibility. It will use multidisciplinary approaches ranging from molecular techniques to whole animal experiments in order to determine how animals integrate external environmental cues to regulate neuroendocrine and physiological changes associated with seasonal reproduction. The research will contribute to unraveling the role of some brain peptides in the control of seasonality and how the brain expression of these peptides is influenced by specific environmental factors. The findings will be relevant to our understanding of the bases of reproductive resilience and they will enhance our comprehension of the effects of some environmental perturbations, such as those potentially associated with global climate warming, on the reproductive physiology of vertebrate populations. The experimental model for the research will be a songbird. Many birds are conspicuous and birds in general are inherently fascinating to the general public. The studies will, therefore, be used to promote basic and advanced biological concepts related to how animals may adapt to the effects of global climate warming and other anthropogenic perturbations of their natural environments. Experimental data will be made publicly available through the Ask-a-Biologist web site, a wildly popular site that promotes science education at all levels, but in particular in high schools. All aspects of the research will involve the mentoring and active participation of undergraduates and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research conducted under this award investigated how animals integrate external environmental information and translate this information into neuroendocrine and physiological changes that are associated with seasonal reproduction. We were particularly interested in the physiological and especially neuroendocrine bases of reproductive resilience. This topic is fundamentally interesting and results obtained from research on this subject have potentially important practical implications. Indeed, these results are likely to enhance our understanding of how organisms adjust reproductively to environmental perturbations, such as those potentially associated with global climate warming and urbanization. These adjustments can in turn influence reproductive fitness and, therefore, also animal populations in general.

Environmental perturbations are often perceived as stressful and a major impetus of our research was, therefore, to better understand how stress affects the reproductive system. We addressed this question using a combined and integrated field and laboratory approach. Field studies investigated behavioral and physiological (endocrine and metabolic) effects of stress. Complementing these studies, laboratory experiments in strictly controlled conditions allowed us to manipulate specific parameters with the goal of establishing causal relationships between changes in the factors being investigated.

An exciting outcome of our work was the finding that acute stress, besides stimulating the secretion of stress hormones as expected, can also rapidly (within 10 min) decrease the secretion of reproductive hormones. We performed several studies to characterize this decrease (time course, magnitude, and duration) and to unravel the mechanisms that are responsible for it, as well as its potential metabolic and behavioral consequences. These studies revealed no apparent causal relationship between elevated secretion of stress hormones (glucocorticoids) and the associated decrease in reproductive hormones, suggesting that this decrease stems from activation of a glucocorticoid-independent, but yet unidentified mechanism. Regulation of the reproductive system activity is often controls by inputs into the central nervous system or the brain or the pituitary gland. Of particular interest, we found that acute stress likely inhibits the secretion of reproductive hormones partly through actions directly on gonads. This conclusion is consistent with recent findings by other research groups and indicates that depending on the situation and presumably the type of environmental signal considered, organisms modulate the activity of their reproductive system at multiple levels. This flexibility has the potential to greatly increase the amount of phenotypic plasticity and resilience that animals can display when facing environmental perturbations. It may, therefore, also facilitate the adjustment of these organisms to environmental perturbations such as those that are taking place and will occur in the future in response to global climate changes and urbanization.

We also found that besides rapidly influencing the activity of the reproductive system, acute stress can induce marked metabolic changes including, in some cases, a decrease in the blood levels of glucose and of a main and potent antioxidant, uric acid. Furthermore, some of these metabolic effects are relatively persistent (> 24 hrs). A major future challenge and goal of our research is to understand the organismal consequences of these metabolic changes. Based on our findings, we developed the novel hypothesis that a decrease in plasma uric acid during stress reflects increased tissue utilization of this antioxidant, in turn resulting in protection against stress-associated elevated oxidative stress.
